required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Evaluation of the Infinity Deep Brain Stimulation System
clinical_study.official_title: Post Market Clinical Follow Up Evaluating the Infinity Deep Brain Stimulation Implantable Pulse Generator System

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this post-market study is to characterize the clinical performance of the Infinity Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) system, including the Implantable Pulse Generator (IPG), directional DBS leads, extensions, iPad clinician programmer, iPod patient controller and related system components.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Single-arm crossover study, with double-blind, randomized sequence of testing for primary endpoint. Although this was a crossover study, the primary endpoint was a double-blind randomized controlled assessment of therapeutic window during the 3-month clinic visit. Subjects received both directional and omnidirectional stimulation, and the order was randomized.
study_design_info.masking_description: Single-arm, open-label design for overall study. Primary endpoint is based on double-blind, randomized testing of omnidirectional and directional DBS during three-month follow visit. Participants are blinded to all details of stimulation for first six months, including details of stimulation testing. Outcomes assessor is blinded to stimulation type for primary and secondary endpoints.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Wider Therapeutic Window With Directional Programming (Superiority)
primary_outcome.description: Therapeutic window is the range of stimulation amplitude that produces symptom relief without causing side effects. Proportion of subjects with a wider therapeutic window using directional stimulation, compared to a threshold of 60%. Based on randomized, double-blind evaluation using within-subject control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Wider Therapeutic Window With Directional Programming (Non-inferiority)
secondary_outcome.description: Therapeutic window is the range of stimulation amplitude that produces symptom relief without causing side effects. The proportion of subjects with wider therapeutic window using directional stimulation will be compared to a performance goal of 60% with a non-inferiority threshold of 40%. Based on randomized, double-blind evaluation using within-subject control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in UPDRS III Score on and Off Stimulation (Medication on) at 3 and 6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Change with stimulation on vs. off in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) part III motor examination at 3 months using omnidirectional stimulation, compared to 6 months using directional stimulation. UPDRS part III contains 27 questions used to measures severity of Parkinson's motor symptoms. The range of scores is 0 to 108, with higher score indicating greater symptoms. Subjects are on medication for the assessment.

arm_group.description: Omnidirectional DBS is used for the first 3 months in all subjects, unless not tolerated. Directional DBS is used for months 3-6 in all subjects with a directional DBS lead. Primary endpoint is based on double-blind testing of omnidirectional vs. directional DBS in randomized order at 3-month follow-up visit.

intervention.description: At the 3-month follow-up, therapeutic window, symptom relief and side effect thresholds are evaluated at the best level for omnidirectional stimulation with the Infinity DBS lead.
At the 3-month follow-up, therapeutic window, symptom relief and side effect thresholds are evaluated using directional contacts at the best segmented level of the Infinity DBS lead.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: The PROGRESS study enrolled a total of 234 participants between January 2017 and January 2019 at 37 sites in Europe, the U.S. and Australia. Of which 195 participants completed 6 months follow-up visit.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of the 234 enrolled participants, there were 230 participants who had initial study programming. Out of 212 participants who completed the 3-month visit, there were 202 with complete primary endpoint data. After the 3-month visit, 17 were withdrawn or lost to follow-up, leaving the number of participants completed as of 195 participants.

group.title: Omnidirectional Followed by Directional DBS
group.description: Omnidirectional DBS is used for the first 3 months in all subjects, unless not tolerated. Directional DBS is used for the following three months up to 6 months, unless not tolerated. At the three and twelve month follow-up visit therapeutic window, symptom relief and side effect thresholds are evaluated at the best level for omnidirectional and directional stimulation with the Infinity DBS lead.

group.title: Omnidirectional Followed by Directional DBS
group.description: Omnidirectional DBS is used for the first 3 months in all subjects, unless not tolerated. Directional DBS is used for the following three months up to 6 months, unless not tolerated. At the three and twelve month follow-up visit therapeutic window, symptom relief and side effect thresholds are evaluated at the best level for omnidirectional and directional stimulation with the Infinity DBS lead.

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Wider Therapeutic Window With Directional Programming (Superiority)
outcome.description: Therapeutic window is the range of stimulation amplitude that produces symptom relief without causing side effects. Proportion of subjects with a wider therapeutic window using directional stimulation, compared to a threshold of 60%. Based on randomized, double-blind evaluation using within-subject control.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed includes subjects for whom data were available at that time of analysis.

group.title: Omnidirectional Followed by Directional DBS
group.description: Omnidirectional DBS is used for the first 3 months in all subjects, unless not tolerated. Directional DBS is used for the following three months up to 6 months, unless not tolerated. At the three and twelve month follow-up visit therapeutic window, symptom relief and side effect thresholds are evaluated at the best level for omnidirectional and directional stimulation with the Infinity DBS lead.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Wider Therapeutic Window With Directional Programming (Superiority)
measure.description: Therapeutic window is the range of stimulation amplitude that produces symptom relief without causing side effects. Proportion of subjects with a wider therapeutic window using directional stimulation, compared to a threshold of 60%. Based on randomized, double-blind evaluation using within-subject control.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed includes subjects for whom data were available at that time of analysis.

analysis.groups_desc: Proportion with wider therapeutic window using directional stimulation was compared to a performance goal of 60%.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Superiority hypothesis was that 95% lower confidence bound on proportion exceeded a threshold of 60%.

Based on randomized, double-blind evaluation using within-subject control.

analysis.groups_desc: Comparison of UPDRS part III on medication from 3 months using omnidirectional stimulation to 6 months using directional stimulation.

event.sub_title: Loss of therapeutic benefit: Lead migration
Worsening of Parkinson's motor symptoms: Tremor

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma
Worsening of Parkinson's motor symptoms: Dyskinesia
Worsening of Parkinson's motor symptoms: Tremor
Sensory disturbance or impairment: Sensory deficit
Worsening of Parkinson's motor symptoms: Abnormal gait
Worsening of Parkinson's motor symptoms: Bradykinesia
Impaired wound healing: Incision site drainage
Suboptimal placement of lead corrected during IPG implant

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
